text: Let me share a story from when I was twenty-one years old. I was living in a small apartment near the city center. I had just started my first job. And uh I was working as a graphic designer.
keypoint: At twenty-one I lived downtown starting my graphic design job

text: My father, who was recovering from a surgery, hadn't been out in – in uh – well I'd say about eight months. He had to use a wheelchair to get around.
keypoint: My father was immobilized in a wheelchair after surgery

text: The only person there with him during the day was a kind neighbor, a lady in her sixties. My younger sister was away at college – so it was just my dad and the neighbor lady at home during the day.
keypoint: A neighbor alone cared for Dad during our absences

text: One day, I got this strong feeling while I was at work. It told me: "If you go to the nearby park during your lunch break and pray for your father's recovery, he'll start to improve."
keypoint: A sudden prompting urged me to pray in the park

text: I looked around my office. I didn't see anyone nearby. So, I went to the park during my break and found a quiet spot there.
keypoint: I slipped out and found a quiet park spot

text: That feeling came back again. I looked around once more. I still didn't see anyone nearby but I decided to take a chance.
keypoint: The urging returned; I decided to act despite embarrassment

text: I wasn't too far from my office, maybe a ten-minute walk. I found a bench to sit on and closed my eyes – uh – uh – that feeling came back once more. I just took a deep breath.
keypoint: Sitting on a bench, the feeling resurfaced as I breathed

text: I was sitting under a big oak tree now. I looked up at the branches above me. Nobody was around.
keypoint: Under a lone oak, I confirmed nobody was watching

text: And uh I said to myself, well now, I had been taught that prayers can make a difference. And that it doesn't hurt to try.
keypoint: Remembering lessons, I reasoned that praying could help Dad

text: I knew I wasn't perfect, but I wanted to help my dad. I'd admit that to anyone. But I was willing to give it a try.
keypoint: Imperfect but determined, I committed to pray for Dad

text: I looked around one more time and then I closed my eyes and said a quiet prayer.
keypoint: I glanced around, closed my eyes, and prayed softly

text: I whispered, "God, I don't know if you're listening. But I ask you to please help my father recover. So he can regain his independence and enjoy life again."
keypoint: I asked God to restore Dad's independence and joy

text: I opened my eyes and went back to work.
keypoint: I ended the prayer and returned to my desk

text: Suddenly, I received a text message from my father. It said, "I just took a few steps with my walker." I – I couldn't believe it. It felt like a sign that my prayer had been heard.
keypoint: Dad texted that he walked; I felt awestruck and hopeful

text: I rushed home after work and saw my father standing in the living room with the help of his walker. He hadn't been able to do that in months without assistance. And there he was, taking small steps.
keypoint: I hurried home and witnessed Dad taking tentative walker steps

text: That was the turning point in his recovery. He continued to improve and regained most of his mobility within a year.
keypoint: That moment marked his steady recovery over the year

text: It's been, what, six or seven years since then? My father is now able to walk without any assistance. He's living life to the fullest, even in his seventies.
keypoint: Years later Dad walks unassisted, enjoying life fully
